title: 115_s2148
content: The Act may be cited as the "Domestic Terrorism Prevention Act of 2017". White supremacists and right-wing extremists are identified as the most significant domestic terrorism threat in the United States. Reports from the Department of Homeland Security and the FBI highlight the danger posed by these groups, with white supremacists responsible for the highest number of homicides compared to other domestic extremist movements. Since 2000, white supremacists and far-right extremists have been responsible for the most domestic terrorist attacks in the United States, with 76 Americans killed by domestic extremists since September 11, 2001. 89 percent of these fatalities were caused by far-right-wing extremists, including incidents like the 2012 Sikh gurdwara shooting in Wisconsin and the 2014 Jewish community center shooting in Kansas. The June 8, 2014, ambush in Las Vegas resulted in the killing of 2 police officers and a civilian by far-right supporters. The June 17, 2015, mass shooting at the Emanuel AME Church in Charleston led to the death of 9 church members by a White supremacist. The November 27, 2015, mass shooting at a Planned Parenthood clinic in Colorado Springs resulted in the killing of a police officer and 2 civilians by an anti-abortion extremist. The March 20, 2017, murder of an African-American man in New York City was allegedly committed by a White supremacist with racist motives. The Anti-Defamation League's Center on Extremism reported that right-wing extremists were responsible for 150 terrorist attacks, including incidents in Portland, Oregon, and Charlottesville, Virginia, where White supremacists killed multiple individuals in acts of domestic terrorism. Attorney General Jeff Sessions confirmed the Charlottesville attack met the definition of domestic terrorism. Between 1993 and 2017, right-wing extremists carried out 150 terrorist acts in the United States, resulting in 255 deaths and over 600 injuries. In 2015, hate groups in the US increased by 14%, including a significant rise in Ku Klux Klan chapters. The number of anti-government militias and "patriot" groups also grew by 14% that year. In 2016, hate crimes increased by almost 5%, with a 19% rise in hate crimes against Americans according to the FBI's annual report. In 2017, hate crimes against American Muslims rose by 19%, with a significant increase in attacks on mosques. A right-wing extremist was charged with murder for a shooting rampage at a mosque in Quebec City. Additionally, between January and July 2017, 63 incidents targeted American mosques with threats, vandalism, or arson. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as "Director" as the head of the FBI, "domestic terrorism" according to the US legal code, "Domestic Terrorism Executive Committee" as a DOJ group monitoring domestic threats, and "Secretary" as the head of Homeland Security. SEC. 4. OFFICES TO COMBAT DOMESTIC TERRORISM. Authorization of Offices To Monitor, Analyze, Investigate, and Prosecute Domestic Terrorism includes the establishment of a Domestic Terrorism Unit in the Department of Homeland Security and a Domestic Terrorism Office in the Department of Justice for investigating and prosecuting incidents of domestic terrorism. The establishment of a Domestic Terrorism Section within the Counterterrorism Division of the FBI is authorized to investigate domestic terrorism activity. Additionally, a joint report on domestic terrorism must be submitted annually by the Secretary of Homeland Security, the Attorney General, and the FBI Director to specific Senate committees. The report submitted annually must include an assessment of the domestic terrorism threat posed by White supremacists, incidents of domestic terrorism since April 19, 1995, and incidents in subsequent reports. The annual report must include incidents of domestic terrorism in the US, a quantitative analysis of domestic terrorism, including FBI assessments and investigations. The annual report must include incidents of domestic terrorism in the US, a quantitative analysis of FBI assessments and investigations, including classifications, subcategories, preliminary investigations, full investigations, incidents, deaths, and injuries. The annual report must include incidents of domestic terrorism in the US, along with details on FBI assessments, investigations, arrests, indictments, and prosecutions related to federal domestic terrorism. The annual report must include incidents of domestic terrorism in the US, along with details on FBI assessments, investigations, arrests, indictments, and prosecutions related to federal domestic terrorism. The report should also cover federal domestic terrorism related convictions and weapons recoveries, with a focus on classification and subcategories. Each report submitted should be unclassified to the greatest extent possible, with a classified annex only if necessary. The Domestic Terrorism Executive Committee is authorized to meet regularly to coordinate with key public safety officials and promote information sharing to combat domestic terrorism. It is co-chaired by the Domestic Terrorism Counsel and a United States Attorney or Assistant United States Attorney. The Domestic Terrorism Executive Committee, co-chaired by the Domestic Terrorism Counsel and a United States Attorney, includes members from the National Security Division of the Department of Justice and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The domestic terrorism offices focus on the most significant threats based on the number of incidents from each category and subclassification in the joint report from the previous year. SEC. 5. TRAINING TO COMBAT DOMESTIC TERRORISM. The State and Local Anti-Terrorism Program funded by the Department of Justice provides training and resources for law enforcement officers to understand and investigate domestic terrorism. Training focuses on significant threats identified in a joint report. Trainers must have expertise and relevant experience in domestic terrorism. A report must be submitted annually. The Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance will submit an annual report to Congress on domestic terrorism training, including training materials and trainer qualifications. Reports will be unclassified, with a classified annex only if necessary. SEC. 6. COMBATTING DOMESTIC TERRORISM THROUGH JOINT TERRORISM TASK FORCES AND FUSION CENTERS. The joint terrorism task forces and fusion centers must share intelligence, assess domestic terrorism activities annually, and develop plans to combat domestic terrorism. Focus should be on the most significant threats based on the number of related incidents. The number of domestic terrorism incidents from each category and subclassification in the joint report for the preceding year determines the focus on combating domestic terrorism. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Such sums as may be necessary will be appropriated to the Department of Justice, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and the Department of Homeland Security to carry out this Act.
